It is not meant to be read through in one sitting, except possibly by those in the front lines concerned with the development and production of school textbooks. Instead, the paper is more of a survey, a primer, and reference as it describes the process of educational publishing, its role in developing human resources and upgrading education. Elements of publishing for schools are described in some detail, such as types, historical development, and economics of publishing; concepts and terms; author/publisher relationships; organizational development and institution building. Special emphasis (including case studies) is given the problems faced by developing countries and ways by which to assist them. Suggestions for a blueprint and for the execution of a project are included.  Preface In the last decade, much attention has been focused on the concept of equity of access to the benefits of development. This should be particularly important in the field of education where wide differences exist among different groups of children in most of the developing countries. Another important concern is to find ways to increase the efficiency, sometimes described as the cost-effectiveness, of systems of education. The well prepared schoolbook, tailored to the needs of the child, is a powerful tool in pursuing the twin goals of equity and of efficiency. While we plead the case of the book,we insist that schoolbook publishing is a field best left to the professional. It requires a wide range of special expertise and talents, but above all and little understood, it needs professional planning and management of a high level of competence. If proof were needed of this statement, the lack of effective publishing industries and of acceptable textbooks in practically all of the developing nations after several decades of "development," speaks for itself. I am profoundly grateful to Mats Hultin and the Education Department of The World Bank for providing me with the motivation and incentive to write this paper on a subject to which I have given considerable thought. This is not to suggest that this paper is meant to be the final word, or that its proposals, suggestions and conclusions are beyond controversy. Rather, I have attempted to put together a framework of references within which vigorous discussions could take place. Writing this paper would not have been possible without the good council and direct help I received from numerous friends and colleagues. I have listed some of their names in the acknowledgments, to those others unnamed my equally heartfelt thanks. For all of us there is a task here waiting to be done.

 Foreword The primary purpose of this paper is to inform World Bank Staff of the place of educational publishing in the world and, more essentially, of its potential role in developing human resources and upgrading education in the less developed countries. The paper concentrates on the complexities of large scale primary/secondary school textbook production, a first priority for most of the new nations. Yet, within the limitations of a brief expository, a more comprehensive approach toward creating viable publishing industries in each new nation is recommended and described. Schoolbooks are only the first step toward literacy and intellectual independence; they must be supplemented, reinforced, and extended by a wide range of reading materials on all subjects, which only a diversified publishing industry can provide. Little is said in this paper about the role of other educational media, such as educational broadcasting and learning machines. While such media attracted a great deal of attention over the last two decades, their early promise has not been fulfilled, even in the industrialized nations. As recent studies have shown, and daily experience proves, the textbook remains the most viable, efficient, and cost-effective means of upgrading and supporting education around the world. In meeting its primary purpose, acquainting the World Bank Staff with the essentials of educational publishing, this. paper may also be of interest to others involved in development programs, including certain officials of developing countries. It attempts to explain the publishing process, rather than content development, and this important distinction should always be kept in mind. Large scale educational publishing is a specialized industrial process much like manufacturing automobiles, establishing a fertilizer plant or a chemical industry. However, this aspect of publishing is little understood or appreciated outside of the industry. In the matter of establishing other industries, the developing countries of necessity look to the specialized skills, the established structures, and the research available from the industrialized nations. The same should hold true for the techniques of establishing a publishing industry and for producing textbooks in a new nation. In describing the publishing process, we use internationally accepted methods and techniques for producing educational materials. Many of the examples and statistics given are from industrialized nations, as such statistics are more readily available and more complete than those frcm other nations. While conditions in the industrialized nations may at times provide a sharp contrast with those in the LDCs, they may also point up surprising similarities.
 By its very nature, publishing for schools, the education of its children, presents a nation with political, cultural, educational, as well as institutional and technical choices. Political choices generally concern the degree of government involvement and control over educational publishing institutions and over the content of textbooks. This paper describes and discusses'several alternatives of government and private se: 'or educational publishing institutions. Obviously, each government must determine the route it wishes to follow. Nevertheless, the publishing processes recommendedin the following pages may be adopted regardless of political persuasion and without fear that they will .taint the desired content of the books,,or that by adopting these methods a new nation will import ideas or attitudes it would not wish to entertain. On the contrary, by using proven methods and skills for establishing and nurturing a publishing industry of its-own, a new nation will be able to create rapidly and effectively content materials which suit its own unique needs, and embody its national philosophy, goals and dreams. It is. for this reason that this paper is dedicated to the writer's many personal friends in the young nations with the hope that it will prove helpful in furthering their goals of cultural and literary independence.

 I. An Introduction to Publishing A. Publishing, a Little Known and Less Understood Profession In spite of the great variety of publishing activities prevalent in the world, most books and articles which have appeared on the subject describe only "trade" publishing, the publication of fiction and non-fiction books, sold through the book trade to the general public. Therefore, the layman is likely to think of publishing in terms of an astute editor who "discovers" a new genius in the process of writing grea-t literature, nurses his talent, and helps him to publish his work. Or, he may simply think of the publisher as a printer. Few people know much about the educational publisher, a less glamorous, more technical and more recent branchof publishing. Yet, educational publishers employ a great many technicians over long periods of time, and at considerable expense, to develop the teaching materials for innumerable classrooms. Besides providing little practical information or insight into the educational publishing process which is useful to those planning for less developed countries, most books written in the industrialized world assume certain conditions and, therefore, spend littletime in explanation of their critical importance to the publishing process. They generally assume a literate,,book-buying public, even though it may not be taken for granted in view of recent inroads by other media. They assume the existence of bookshops, mail-order houses and book clubs and, as often as not, reliable postal services, possibly with preferential rates for educational materials, in addition to other effective means of getting books safely to distributors and customers. In the developed nations, with their highly competitive publishing industries, school systems as a matter of course depend on a wide selection -of teaching materials from which to choose. At primary and secondary school levels, governments generally provide loan,'free textbooks with public funds. In conseauence, teacher and school are able to select a textbook appropriate .or their students in each major subject area, i.e., language arts, social studies, mathematics and science. They are able to supplement these materials 'or the slow learner or the gifted student. Additionally, teachers in the developed nations have the time and resources to produce their own teaching aids; or mav turn to audiovisual materials for support and enrichment.

Versatility, effectiveness, and low cost make textbooks an educational bargain. In the developing countries conditions are much different from those described above. However, little attention has been given to the unique problems of LDCs and how they might profit from the experiences of other nations in providing effective learning materials for their children, and to the difficulties of establishing a publishing industry or enterprise in a new nation. These are important topics because of the critical contribution which educational materials can make toward achieving academic standards and developing human resources. As far as feasible within the confines of a short paper, we attempt to relate the characteristics of educational publishing to the requirements of the new nations. We focus on the problems encountered when planning for development and, within these limits, provide a primer on the publishing industry. Thus, we describe and relate the special skills and techniques which are required, outline and explain investments, costs, and the organization of a publishing house. In the final section of the paper, we strive to relate all of this information directly to the needs of LDCs, and to provide concrete suggestions on how to blueprint and execute publishing projects. B. Characteristics of the Publishing Industry 1. The Types of Publishing. There are many essentially different publishing activities: newspapers, magazines, scholarly and trade journals, as well as different categories of book publishing. Publishing institutions could be government monopolies in socialist-communist countries, or a mixture of government, commercial and nonprofit private institutions in other parts of the world, including many of the LDCs. In socialist-communist countries all publishing activities are political in the sense that they are regulated bv and serve the state; by contrast,most book publishing by commercial publishers is nonpolitical and largely dictated by market considerations. This is an important distinction for the new nations to ponder. in many instances their laws do not discriminate between newspaper publishing which tends to be political and, therefore, may be subject to various controls, and general commercial book publishing which only rarely carries the same political impact.

Historical Development of Publishing. As with many other industries, publishing had the time to develop in the industrial world. From modest beginnings more than five hundred years ago, usually centered around a university, a religious institution or a press, the publishing industry has grown large, presently publishing over 100,000 new titles annually worldwide, with around one million titles in print! The explosion of knowledge, the extension of compulsory general education to include 10, 12, or even 13 years of schooling with a concomitant growth oE tertiary enrolLments, the post-World War II baby boom - all have contributed to the massive growth of publishing activities in the industrialized countries. This growth of the publishing industries has been heavily dependent on the expenditure of public furnds for education, for libraries and for research. In certain countries, we would estimate that close to 40% of the annual sales of books are financed by public funds, which include the free/loan suDolv of textbooks to schools. (This coint will be further discussed in Section-D of this paper.)

Even though publishing has grown rapidly in the industrialized nations and isno longer the'sole preserve of the gentleman publisher or the family- owned house, certain basic aspects have changed little or not at all. As an example, publishing remains small if compared to other industries in terms of sales , capital investment, or employment. Thus,$4.6 billion of sales of USA publishers in 1977 may be roughly equivalent to the sales of the 42nd largest U.S. corporation or, even more startling, in a good year the equivalent of the annual profits of General Motors. The previously close association of publisher and printer in one house has by now almost completely disappeared, and most publishers own little in the way of machinery,- equipment, or even buildings. Instead, they tend to have considerable investments in book inventories, and especially in the creativity of people: authors, editors, designers; production, marketing, promotion and distribution specialists. In publishing it is still possible to start a small enterprise with a novel idea, a gifted author and a little money, but it is becoming increasingly difficult to compete successfully in major areas of school publishing, for example. To do so requires financial investments in developmental work and in inventory,'all of which is quite beyond the reach of the small entrepreneur. A typical publishing house grows slowly. It takes years to build a stable' of authors and to develop a backlist of titles of sufficient strength and longevity to provide a solid basis for further growth. This is especially true of educational publishing. A typical college text may take three years to develop and write after the author's proposal has been accepted by a publisher, and yet another year to produce. Depending how quickly methodologies and research cause the'subject matter to change, the text will be revised within 3-to-5 years. Secondary school texts demand a similar schedule, except that their revision cycle may be closer to five years. A basal primary series, on the other hand, will require 4-to-6 years for development and production of the first edition. In the United Kingdom, books are a larger market than cheese, about the same as eggs, but ,less than. half the market for milk, remarks one commentator. (Publishers Weekly, October 2, 1978.)

It is axiomatic that a potential author has to be teaching the subject material if he is to write an effective textbook. He must be able to test his ideas on his students and to receive input or, at least, reviews from his colleagues. Consequently, textbook writing grows out of successful and inventive teaching; each author learns and grows with the text he is developing. Quite often a potential author fails in his efforts. College textbook publishers find that one out of three or four authors they sign does not produce a publishable manuscript. Indeed, some never produce a manuscript. Obviously, in such cases, much effort and time is wasted by both author and publisher. As shall be seen subsequently when we discuss school publishing, the considerable investment of time and money required to prodUce a basal primary school series demands a different author-publisher relationship, with more reliance by the publisher on selecting and controlling the author team and more in-house production of materials.  II. Textbook Publishing: Background and Definitions A. Teaching and Textbooks Most good teaching has structure and variety, aims at presenting con- cepts, content, problems and exercises in ways that motivate the student to learn and that reinforce each other, spiral and repeat. Most lessons are or- ganized and divided into units that fit classroom situations as well as teaching periods. A good teacher individualizes his/her methods to suit the range of learning abilities represented in the classroom. - A good textbook should do much the same. Just as a lesson taught by a teacher is more than chalk and talk, a textbook page, a unit, or chapter, should be more than a recital of fact or a setting out of exercises. It must be visual: offer structure, variety, and present its materials in different ways; it should motivate, spiral, and reinforce. A textbook must be organized and divided into units that fit the classroom situation, and the time available for teaching the subject. It should provide for individualization, for the different abilities represented in the classroom. Good textbook materials are as rare as outstanding teachers. They require creative and seasoned authorship, developed and supported by a pro- fessional organization specializing in educational publishing. If the pro- cess is little understood outside the profession, nevertheless, technicues exist for mastering it which may be applied to different subjects, to books as well as supplementary materials, to other languages, and cultures. Textbook projects are initiated almost daily in every nation of the world. They are undertaken by widely diverse organizations and individuals for a variety of reasons. Recent studies of conditions in the LDCs, together with the daily class- room experience of thousands of teachers and students everywhere, indicate that the textbook, defined as including all printed materials used in edu- cation, is the single most potent and cost-effective instrument for raising academic standards in the classroom. Consequently, textbook projects, as an influential aid to development, have received increased attention by governments of less developed countries, and by the national and international organizations devoted to providing them with assistance.

Early educational development on the North American Continent had elements in -common with the less developed nations. Universal compulsory education was introduced in North America at a time when there was a general lack of trained teachers, and educational facilities were spread thir.ly over great distances. Also, education was assigned a major role in nation-building, as wave upon wave of imuigrants from widely differing backgrounds had to be absorbed into the system. Under these circumstances, the textbook became a major educational tool, a support for both the student and teacher, and its development gave rise to educational publishing techniques which can be of substantial assistance to the less developed countries. An example is the "teachers' edition," or -"teacher resource book," which today accompanies most basal primary or secondary school textbooks published by responsible publishers in the United States, Canada, Europe, Latin America, and parts of Asia and Africa. - B. A Look at the Past and Present In previous sections, we discussed at some length various aspects of book publishing, and saw that developed countries worked toward establishing a publishing industry and continue to support its growth in many ways. Certain countries, especially those belonging to major language groups, such as, English or Spanish, traditionally depended during their development period on the publications of a "mother" country; other nations need to look for their models elsewhere. However, sooner or later every sovereign nation needs its own vigorous and creative publishing industry. It needs to give official recognition and support to the unique role of the book in nation- building, cultural development, education, growth of a national literature, self-improvement and information. The post-World War II world has seen a great improvement in general educational standards. With it came an unprecedented growth of book publishing, as well as the development of new media for education, information and entertainment. In much of the world, the flow of books and of ideas in education has crossed international boundaries, protected by widely accepted copyright laws, and the UNESCO Free Flow Agreement (Florence Convention). Governments, especially those of LDCs, are spending increasing amounts of money on their educational systems. Many nations subsidize certain activities, including the export, of their publishing industries. "Trade follows the Book," coined by Sir Stanley Unwin, has been a widely accepted slogan. Most industrialized nations have developed programs to support the book by campaigns designed to make their people more book-conscious and by massive purchases of learning materials with public funds. Many of these nations have attempted in various ways to make their books more readily accessable to countries which cannot afford to cav their full price. Commercial publishers,with the support of their authors, created ingenious schemes to cope with book hunger in The Third World through the publication of inexpensive reprint editions, and by granting, often for token fees, translation rights in so-called non-commercial languages.
 - 46 - The Soviet Union and, to an extent, China have subsidized export of translations, often in English or Spanish, of their textbooks and national literature. Many of these activitiesare helpful, and few actuall. harm the less developed countries. Some national aid programs provided, at least temporarily, needed books to students at tertiary levels at prices they could afford to pay. In other instances, translations into local languages were actively sponsored. Nevertheless, in few if any cases did these activities result in the establish- ment of strong national publishing industries, nor did they manage to bridge the "Book Gap." Today, the hunger for books may be greater than ever before and,with it, the need to institutionalize book publishing in the LDCs. Yet, most developed nations, the United States a discouraging example, have actually abandoned book support programs or greatly reduced their efforts in this direction. It is fair to ask what went wrong with these well meaning efforts, especially if the intention is to improve the record. Observing the record in both developed and developing countries, it soon becomes clear that a publishing industry cannot be created, nor can it survive for long without a major commitment by government to nurture and protect this industry. Such a commitment requires a long-range policy of substantial investments in education and educational materials, most importantly, perhaps, appropriate and constant public funding for the provision of basic school textbooks, the development of school and national libraries, for research, and,more generally,for promoting literacy and the reading habit. Without determined, long-range support by the national government, even well planned and financed book assistance programs offer only temporary relief at best. Secondly, most often,book assistance programs are restricted in time and effort to short-term or one-shot programs. They lack the necessary continuity and institution-building required to create publishing expertise and permanent publishing institutions. These observations appear to be exceedingly basic and obvious. Yet, it is curious to note that many publishers in the industrialized world are them- selves only dimly aware that their very existence depends on the expenditures, the direct and indirect support, of their governments.

With countless LDC book projects, people exert themselves to produce the books, labor to get them to schools for loan/free use, and then find to their astonish- ment and disappointment that teachers carefully lock up the received bounty and adamantly refuse to use it. The reasons for such surprising resistance may be varied, some as basic as gover.nment regulations which make individual teachers personally responsible for damage or loss of books. In most cases, however, such books remain on the shelves because teachers have been ill-prepared for their arrival. They may feel auite justly that their needs have not been taken into consideration in the preparation of these books. In most cases, teachers are not keptinformed of the aims of a textbook project, are not properly instructed in the use of the books they are to receive, or are given woefully inadequate teachers' edit-ons. Mass distribution of new textbooks generally constitutes a drastic change in the traditional teaching methcds practiced in most LDCs. Such a change may appear threatening to the teacher; therefore, the acceptance of new teaching materials and their constructive use require careful advance preparation, promotion and publicity, and, perhaps, even the involvement of parents and the general oublic.
 - 70 - In addition, a well structure program of teacher training should accompany the introduction of new schoolbooks. As has been pointed out elsewhere in this paper, educational publishers often provide pre- adoption seminars, as well as post-adoption "trouble shooting" workshops when a school district purchases new textbooks. With large-scale schemes introducing new textbooks to teachers who may have had little experience in teaching from a textbook, one would have to go considerably further. The situation of these LDC teachars is more akin to what went on in the schools of the industrialized nations during the 1950's and 1960's. At that time, radically new methods for teaching, for example, modern mathematics and science, were introduced into the school systems. It became then necessary to launch massive programs for retraining teachers. Often, these programs consisted of 3-6 week summer courses, sponsored by government-funded agencies, which teachers attended during vacation period. It has been pointed out in this paper that well prepared textbooks, together with well conceived teachers' editions, not only aid students in their studies, but may, in fact, constitute a form of in-service training for teachers. However, for this to happen, working teachers must be prepared for their new task through extensive in-service training. Teacher training colleges and universities should include in their curricula analysis and demonstration of the use of textbooks and of teachers' editions, which government may be supplying to schools.
 -71 - VII. A Final Word Books are fundamental to education and all children deserve the very best. The importance of adequate schoolbook supplies toward raising academic standards has been insufficiently recognized in past efforts; provision of textbooks, other teaching materials, and library supplies has had low priority with budget planners; existing models of effective textbooks and professional publishing expertise have been generally disregarded, often out of ignorance rather than by design. It is time for a change.

Since this is such an important topic, I would ask, knowing fully well how busy you are, that you share some of your thoughts and experiences with me, point me to additional sources of-information, where convenient, and make me aware of any literature or research which exists. As some of you know, I have become involved again with the development of educational publishing in the Third World. Since 1975, I have been working on several projects financed by the World Bank, in Indonesia and The Philippines, as an occasional consultant. However, other areas in Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Arab World face like problems. I have been asked to develop guidelines, to define and advise on roles and relationships between public sector and private sector publishing, especially as they relate to textbooks at elementary and secondary level. I hesitate to put forward my own feelings until I have checked the experiences and feelings of colleagues and friends I respect. I need your help. In an effort to simplify a complex issue steeped in controversy and apparently dominated by extreme views on both sides, you may or may not wish to accept these postulates: 1. A sovereign nation needs a vigorous and creative publishing industry. It must give official recogniticn and support to the unique role the book plays in nation building, cultural development, growth of a national literature, education, self-improvement, and information. 2. Every government, from the socialist countries to that of the USA. has a legitimate concern in education and is engaged in publishing activities. Therefore, it is not a question of whether a government should publish at all, but rather to what degree it should participate, and how it should define the respective roles and responsibilities of the public and private sectors.
 - 73 - 3. Third World countries are under great pressures to upgrade and make more relevant their educational systems. In many instances, governments have inherited educational traditions which are oral, or at least not markedly textbook oriented. Classroom teachers do not necessarily feel the need for elaborate textbook materials, may in fact be threatened by them. This is not to say that television, visuals, audio materials do not have a rightful place in teaching. If one broadly accepts the foregoing, how can developing nations best develop, produce, and distribute on a cost-effective basis the vast quantitites of text materials their schools require? doc.abstracts: Major conclusions and suggestions are: (a) textbooks, teacher editions, and allied materials are the most consistent factors in upgrading academic achievement, especially for poorer schools with less qualified teachers; (b) textbooks, etc. are cost effective tools which greatly enhance the efficiency of an educational system; (c) the development, production, and distribution of textbook materials should not be carried out in isolation and without professional competence; (d) rather institution building, teacher training, long-range government commitment, a total look at the book industry of a developing country are prerequisites for success; (e) the area of educational publishing lends itself well to Bank financing, which can provide impetus, technical assistance, and smooth out the intially high developmental costs. It fits in well with Bank concerns regarding equity of access to education, and building the human resources needed for economic development.
